awd_titl_txt: OPP-PRF Pygoscelis  Penguin Response to Potential Prey Retention along the West Antarctic Peninsula
awd_abstract_narration:
Pygoscelis penguins are central place foragers during the summer while they raise their chicks. They leave and return to the same colony location after hunting for food and rely on the availability of Antarctic krill, their primary food source. This research focuses on whether penguin diets and colony location reflect the retention of prey around and near colonies on the West Antarctic Peninsula. Eddies and other oceanographic processes may facilitate prey retention at certain locations, driving penguin colony establishment and success. 

This project hypothesizes that Pygoscelis penguin diets will be composed of more Antarctic krill (Euphausia superba) when local prey retention is high, possibly due to subsurface eddies. This hypothesis will be tested using satellite-based estimates of Pygoscelis penguin diet composition using multispectral sensor data to estimate nitrogen values and infer trophic level. Prey retention will be calculated along the peninsula using the Regional Ocean Modeling System (ROMS). Simulated particles and diel vertical migration will be used to mimic krill behavior. These particles can be experimentally seeded across multiple depths in multiple years to assess residence times in the system. Using penguin colony data from the Mapping Application for Penguin Populations and Projected Dynamics (MAPPPD), the PI will correlate diet and retention metrics to local penguin colony growth and persistence and build a predictive model of where colonies may form in the future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goals of the Office of Polar Programs Postdoctoral Research Fellowship titled “Pygoscelis Penguin Response to Potential Prey Retention along the West Antarctic Peninsula” were to 1) broadly understand krill transport and accumulation dynamics on broad spatial scales and 2) understand the role of krill accumulation in penguin distributions along the West Antarctic Peninsula. This was accomplished by releasing krill with realistic vertical migration behaviors into a physical ocean model simulating the ocean environment around the Peninsula. We found that krill originating from the Bellingshausen and Weddell Seas around the Peninsula were nearly completely isolated from each other and provided krill, the preferred food source for the Pygoscelis penguins that occupy the Peninsula, to different colonies. While transit and retention times did not correlate with penguin abundance on broad spatial scales, there were spatial overlaps between regions where transit times were long and retention was small and intense krill fishing pressure. This suggests that in years with poor krill recruitment and intense fishing pressure that the krill fishing industry may significantly compete with top predators for resources. Furthermore, areas of high transit times and low retention also overlapped with a region of the Peninsula known as the Adelie Gap. In this region, there are no Adelie penguin colonies, despite Adelie penguins’ ability to reach these areas. We hypothesize that the long transit times and low retention of krill in the region could prevent the penguins from colonizing the region due to low food availability at the start of their breeding season, which starts the earliest of the three Pygoscelis penguins.

 

Our second goal was to understand the role of persistent krill accumulation on breeding habitat suitability for Pygoscelis penguins on the Peninsula. In this, we also quantified the relative role of oceanographic versus terrestrial drivers of habitat suitability. We found that persistent prey accumulation was important for all three species. We also found that the relative contribution of oceanographic and terrestrial covariates differed across the three species. We used these results to predict where all three species could form new colonies, or have currently undiscovered colonies, under current climate conditions. We found that gentoos, which have rapidly expanded their range southward over the past three decades, may continue to extend their range southward into Marguerite Bay. This study provided important insights into the drivers of current habitat use in Pygoscelis penguins and provides a framework that could be used to examine how suitable habitats may shift in future climate conditions. 

 

While not an explicit goal of this study, the use of physical ocean modeling allowed us to examine both the transport pathways and accumulation of buoyant marine debris along the Peninsula. We found that buoyant debris may accumulate the most around the South Shetland Islands due to converging current patterns from the Weddell and Bellingshausen Seas. We also used existing observations of marine debris and used our simulations to find possible source locations for these debris. Most of the debris observed on the continental shelf likely came from other areas on the shelf. This suggests that marine debris is coming from localized pollution, rather than other regions of the Southern Ocean, or other ocean basins, and then transported to the area by the Antarctic Circumpolar Current. 

 

As part of this project, several undergraduate students have learned about data analysis and coding skills through paid internship opportunities. One student also attended her first scientific conference - the 2024 Ocean Sciences Meeting in New Orleans. Furthermore, I taught several students and classrooms about careers in ocean sciences through outreach opportunities. This included working with the Stony Brook Women in Science and Engineering high school program, and outreach events like Skype a Scientist and Letters to a Pre-Scientist. 

 


Last Modified: 02/21/2025
Modified by: Katherine L Gallagher
